Package common

Class DesktopConsole

java.lang.Object
common.DesktopConsole
public final class DesktopConsole
extends java.lang.Object
Provides similar functionality to Console but utilizing a desktop interface.

  • Method Summary

    Modifier and Type Method Description
    static void format​(java.lang.String fmt, java.lang.Object... args)

  • Method Details

    • format

      public static void format​(java.lang.String fmt, java.lang.Object... args)
      Displays a formatted string to the user
      Parameters:
      fmt - A format string as described in Format string syntax
      args - Arguments referenced by the format specifiers in the format string. If there are more arguments than format specifiers, the extra arguments are ignored. The number of arguments is variable and may be zero. The maximum number of arguments is limited by the maximum dimension of a Java array as defined by The Java™ Virtual Machine Specification. The behaviour on a null argument depends on the conversion.
      Throws:
      java.lang.IllegalStateException - If no valid console implementation could be found

    • printf

      public static void printf​(java.lang.String format, java.lang.Object... args)
      A convenience method to display a formatted string to the user

      An invocation of this method of the form con.printf(format, args) behaves in exactly the same way as the invocation of 

      con.format(format, args)
      .
      Parameters:
      format - A format string as described in Format string syntax
      args - Arguments referenced by the format specifiers in the format string. If there are more arguments than format specifiers, the extra arguments are ignored. The number of arguments is variable and may be zero. The maximum number of arguments is limited by the maximum dimension of a Java array as defined by The Java™ Virtual Machine Specification. The behavior on a null argument depends on the conversion.
      Throws:
      java.lang.IllegalStateException - If no valid console implementation could be found

    • readLine

      public static java.lang.String readLine()
      Reads a single line of text from the user
      Returns:
      A string containing the line read from the user
      Throws:
      java.lang.IllegalStateException - IllegalStateException If no valid console implementation could be found

    • readLine

      public static java.lang.String readLine​(java.lang.String fmt, java.lang.Object... args)

      Parameters:

      args - Arguments referenced by the format specifiers in the format string. If there are more arguments than format specifiers, the extra arguments are ignored. The number of arguments is variable and may be zero. The maximum number of arguments is limited by the maximum dimension of a Java array as defined by The Java™ Virtual Machine Specification. The behavior on a null argument depends on the conversion.r
      Returns:
      A string containing the line read from the user
      Throws:
      java.lang.IllegalStateException - IllegalStateException If no valid console implementation could be found

    • readPassword

      public static char[] readPassword()
      Reads a password or passphrase from the user
      Returns:
      A character array containing the password or passphrase read from the user
      Throws:
      java.lang.IllegalStateException - IllegalStateException If no valid console implementation could be found
      See Also:
      Console.readPassword(), readPassword()

    • readPassword

      public static char[] readPassword​(java.lang.String fmt, java.lang.Object... args)
      Provides a formatted prompt, then reads a password or passphrase from the user
      Parameters:
      fmt - A format string as described in Format string syntax
      args - Arguments referenced by the format specifiers in the format string. If there are more arguments than format specifiers, the extra arguments are ignored. The number of arguments is variable and may be zero. The maximum number of arguments is limited by the maximum dimension of a Java array as defined by The Java™ Virtual Machine Specification. The behavior on a null argument depends on the conversion.r
      Returns:
      A character array containing the password or passphrase read from the user
      Throws:
      java.lang.IllegalStateException - IllegalStateException If no valid console implementation could be found
      See Also:
      Console.readPassword​(java.lang.String, java.lang.Object...), readPassword​(java.lang.String, java.lang.Object...)
